ratings.question_text: I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: What is the name of your TA?
comments: Matt Carrol
matt carroll
Matt Carroll
Matt Carroll
Matt Carroll
Matthew Carroll
Matt Carroll

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-10, if you wish
comments: Terrific class great instruction

Class atmosphere and opportunities for participation and discussion were great. Very valuable course for anyone who plans to work in land conservation/management in the intermountain west and the southeast.

1. Some reading materials were missing from the classes website.3. Presentations would have worked better with a smaller class. With a class the size of ours one presentation would have been sufficient, and would have prevented us from extended classes into reading week.6. The pace of the class was just right for the first half of the semester when the science of fire was the focus. During the second half the pace slowed and topics weren't as well covered. Euromi, Bruce Keleman, Stella and Tom were good speakers, but the CT-based speaker wasn't very good. Would have preferred lectures instead of the movies shown (was hard to hear during one of them because people, including the TA, kept talking throughout).
Question 2: Ann is one of my favorite teachers at FES. She is very enthusiastic and encourages the class to participate. She always makes time for our questions.
Ann is an extremely open engaging professor. Very excited about the subject matter and willing to dedicate lots of time to answering questions.
Ann Camp
discussing controversial/current issues regarding fire policy and management

The course is very applicable to on-the-ground work, though it covers theoretical aspects well too. Many of my classes rely too much on theory and scientific papers, while this class gave me more "real life" skills.

Relevance to my intended research. Subject material is fascinating. S-130/S-190 supplemental course (rate of learning during it was incredibe and it complemented what was happening in the normal class very well).Coverage of the science of fire.Professor's interest and passion for the topic.

The team dynamic between the TA (Matt) and Ann. They worked well together and complimented each other's knowledge and experience in the subject.Good opportunities for class discussion added alot to the class as well.

narratives.question_text: The things about this course most in need of improvement are:
comments: I'd like to have a couple more field trips.
tough to say
I can't really think of anything...
Adding another field trip would be good, even if it didn't directly involve burning.

Multiple choice on midterm was confusing.Presentation/paper schedule needs to be re-evaluated.As indicated in Question 11, the structure/material of the second half of the course could be improved.Professor could be better prepared to deliver the lecture (minimize the amount of reading directly from the Powerpoint slides).

Could be taught with a bit more organization.The end of the course sort of tapered off without real clear direction, content, or organization. It would have been nice to have more content added to the final sections of the class.

narratives.question_text: What was the availability and quality of help you received of the instructor and TA?
comments: Ann is very available and helpful. Matt is the same.
Very good; open and helpful
awesome- he gave two lectures himself and was always willing to help.

Both were very helpful. The Ann Camp was very willing to structure the class to meet the goals of the students. Discussion were very active, due at least in part to Ann and Matt leading these discussion effectively.
Didn't request any additional help.
Great. Ann is an excellent mentor and always available for students. Matt was also great, although he was not always available simply because he is extremely busy.

narratives.question_text: Discuss if you wish how this course fits into your overall program.
comments: This class is essential for anyone interested in forestry, forest conservation, or terrestrial ecology in the Western US or other fire-regulated landscapes.
Integral to my interests and career plans. An essential part of understanding Nature!
I want to work in forest management/land conservation in fire-prone ecosystems.

Though I am not a forestry student, I think this class will be useful for me in the general land management and conservation I am interested in. It provides a prime example of the interdisciplinary skills I was seeking at Yale.

Fire is a critical natural disturbance and this class provides an in depth understanding of the role of fire in land and forest management, so it rounds out my forest ecology and forest management education.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: I wanted to take another course with Ann and learn about the subject matter.
To get to know fire and fire policy
because I wanted to learn in-depth about how fire affects ecosystems, and because I know I like Ann Camp's classes
I thought it sounded interesting. It should be helpful in working with or for the Forest Service. The small class size allowed me to really get to know some interesting students.

It was directly relevant to the research I intend to conduct this summer. It also is an area in which I'd like to focus after graduation. Knew that the professor had a lot of experience with the topic.I think that fire will be an increasingly important and powerful disturbance as climate change progresses.Because a smoker jumper was the TA! (JUST KIDDING!)
Understanding the role of fire and fire policy is critical to managing landscapes in the western U.S. where I plan on working.

narratives.question_text: Did it live up to your expectations?
comments: Yes
Yes, and more
definitely
Yes
Yes. I'm glad that most of the class was able to participate in a prescribed burn at Yale Myers and in the S-130/S-190 courses. They are easily the most memorable portions of the course.
For the most part. Again, more content towards the end of the semester would help.

narratives.question_text: Did you get out of it what you expected?
comments: Yes
I got more out than I expected
sure did
Yes
Yes, I feel like I have a fundamental understanding of fire in order to inform the research I'll perform this summer.
Yes

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: Nothing toshow..

narratives.question_text: For students taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Enjoy!
Great Course, interesting subject. Has deep implications.

Make a point to take S-130/S-190. Attend any prescribed burns that occur at Yale-Myers.Choose your paper topic carefully and start working on presentations and the paper itself early. Try to get concrete information about the presentation schedule at the beginning of the semester.
Do the reading and then be prepared to keep the class more discussion oriented because you'll get more out of it then simply hearing powerpoint-based lectures.
